Award.AwardTitle: Neron models, singularities of normal functions, and Hodge loci
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI proposes to apply methods from the theory of mixed Hodge modules to the study of Hodge classes and normal functions, in order to solve several problems about singularities of normal functions and the locus of Hodge classes. The main idea is the construction of natural complex-analytic extension spaces, which make it possible to apply differential-geometric and topological methods to the above problems, and which can also be used to define numerical invariants. To date, the PI has successfully carried out one portion of this, namely the construction of complex-analytic Neron models. He proposes to use his results to describe graph closures of admissible normal functions, to carry out a local study of singularities, and to obtain a classification theorem. The PI also proposes to introduce Poincare bundles of Neron models, both to define numerical invariants for pairs of normal functions and to make progress on the question of the existence of singularities.

The proposed work is connected with the program of M. Green and P. Griffiths, and bears on the Hodge conjecture. The general philosophy is to understand the geometry of a complex algebraic variety with the help of differential geometry and topology. The proposed methods can be used, for instance, to study Noether-Lefschetz loci on Calabi-Yau threefolds; this example is interesting because we have very intriguing numerical predictions made by physicists for these loci.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The geometry of nonsingular complex projective varieties is a rich and classical subject. On the one hand, such a variety can be defined by homogeneous polynomial equations inside complex projective space, and can be studied using methods from algebraic geometry. On the other hand, it is also a compact complex manifold with a natural Kähler metric, and can be studied using methods from differential geometry. An example of this is the Hodge decomposition of the cohomology groups of a complex projective manifold; such a decomposition is called a Hodge structure, and Hodge theory is the study of Hodge structures and their interactions with the geometry of the underlying varieties. The most important open problem in Hodge theory is the Hodge conjecture, which predicts the existence of algebraic subvarieties corresponding to certain cohomology classes called Hodge classes. Several years ago, Mark Green and Philip Griffiths proposed an equivalent formulation in terms of singularities of normal functions; they also conjectured that the zero locus of an admissible normal function on an algebraic variety should be an algebraic subvariety.

The goal of this proposal was to apply methods from the theory of mixed Hodge modules to the study of Hodge classes and normal functions. The PI has constructed complex-analytic Néron models with good properties, which lead to a new proof for the above-mentioned conjecture by Green and Griffiths about zero loci of admissible normal functions. The PI has also introduced a notion of "limit Hodge class" and has proved -- by generalizing the famous theorem of Eduardo Cattani, Pierre Deligne, and Aroldo Kaplan about the locus of Hodge classes -- that the "locus of limit Hodge classes" forms an analytic space with the same finiteness properties as the locus of Hodge classes. In certain cases, such as for the family of hyperplane sections of a Calabi-Yau threefold, this result can be used to associate a "virtual number of points" to each irreducible component of the locus of limit Hodge classes. Together with Greg Pearlstein, the PI has proved a new algebraicity result for infinitesimal invariants of admissible normal functions; in another joint paper with Morihiko Saito, the PI studied the field of definition of the locus of Hodge classes.

Together with Mircea Mustata and Claude Sabbah, the PI organized a week-long workshop about mixed Hodge modules for around 25 participants (Clay Mathematics Institute, August 2013). In addition, the PI helped to organize a conference about Hodge theory and complex algebraic geometry (Ohio State University, May 2013), where one purpose was to introduce graduate students and young researchers to recent developments in Hodge theory. The PI gave two introductory lectures about mixed Hodge modules during a workshop on geometric methods in representation theory (Sanya, January 2013), with the goal of explaining this difficult topic to researchers from a different part of mathematics, and subsequently published a longer survey article about the same topic.

The recent work on normal functions, including that by the PI, was the topic of a Bourbaki lecture by Francois Charles (Paris, January 2013); the purpose of the Bourbaki seminar is to discuss important recent developments in all areas of mathematics.
